column2: The visuals in this movie are straight-up insane. James Cameron did it again!
I was not emotionally prepared for Neteyam's death. My heart is broken.
The way they animated the water is next level. It looks so real!
Quaritch coming back as an Avatar is the ultimate 'I'm back' moment. Wild.
The Tulkun are so majestic. I want one as a pet.
Can we talk about Spider saving Quaritch at the end? My guy has major identity issues.
The Metkayina clan's design is beautiful. Love the different look for the reef Na'vi.
Kiri connecting with Eywa and controlling the sea life was a total power move.
This movie is basically a 3-hour ad for scuba diving on Pandora.
Payakan the Tulkun being an outcast who then saves the day is the best character arc.
The family dynamic with Jake and his kids is so relatable, even if they're giant blue aliens.
Lo'ak getting the blame for everything but then being the one to save them was peak middle child energy.
The underwater scenes are just breathtaking. I could watch them for hours.
The moment the RDA burns down the forest village... I felt that. Pure rage.
I can't believe how much they made me care about a space whale. Payakan is the GOAT.
The final battle on the ship is an absolute masterpiece of action filmmaking.
Kiri's connection to Grace is so mysterious. Can't wait to see where that goes.
The way Neytiri went full beast mode after Neteyam died was both terrifying and awesome.
This movie really makes you want to protect the oceans.
Jake learning to be a father instead of a soldier is a great character journey.
The sound design when they're underwater is so immersive.
The idea of 'recoms' is a crazy way to bring back old villains.
The kids' storyline is the heart of this movie, no cap.
Spider's choice at the end creates so much drama for the next movie. What is he thinking?!
The visual storytelling is top-tier. You could watch this on mute and still get it.
The Tulkun hunt scene was genuinely hard to watch. So brutal.
All the new sea creatures were so creative and beautiful.
Neteyam's death was the saddest moment in the whole franchise. I wasn't ready.
The way the Metkayina move and swim is so different from the Omatikaya. Great world-building.
Quaritch's Recom literally has his human skull crushed in his hand at one point. That's metal.
The tension between Jake and Neytiri over how to protect their kids felt so real.
The underwater sign language is such a cool detail.
Kiri having a seizure after connecting to the Spirit Tree was so unexpected.
The cultural clash between the forest Na'vi and the reef Na'vi was super interesting.
Jake Sully giving up his role as war chief to protect his family was a massive turning point.
The whole movie is a vibe. Just pure escapism.
The fact that Kiri is basically Pandora Jesus is a theory I'm 100% behind.
The bond between Lo'ak and Payakan was the best part of the movie for me.
The final shot of Jake and his family with the Metkayina feels like a new beginning.
I need more of Ronal. She was fierce.
Lo'ak being the 'outcast' son who finds his place with another outcast (Payakan) is *chef's kiss*.
The kids getting captured was so stressful to watch.
The sinking ship sequence was like Titanic on steroids.
Does anyone else feel like the science behind the recoms is a bit sketchy? lol
Neytiri threatening to kill Spider was the most intense scene. You could feel her pain and rage.
The underwater chase scenes were incredible.
The way the parents' grief was portrayed after Neteyam's death was so powerful and raw.
Tonowari is such a cool and wise leader.
Kiri being able to breathe underwater indefinitely is a huge deal they just kinda glossed over!
The design of the new RDA ships and tech was pretty slick.
When the Tulkun join the final battle, I was literally cheering in the theater.
Jake really went from 'oorah' to 'I see you' and now he's a full-on dad.
The moment Jake realizes running was a mistake and they have to fight back. CHILLS.
The bioluminescence in the water was stunning.
So Quaritch now knows what it's like to be Na'vi. That's gonna complicate things.
I feel so bad for Spider, caught between two worlds.
Neytiri still hates Spider even after he helps them. That's cold.
The training montage of the Sully kids learning the way of water was awesome.
The final fight between Jake and Quaritch felt so personal this time.
Are we just gonna ignore the fact that Kiri might be a virgin birth conceived by Eywa???
The movie is long but it earns its runtime. Every scene feels important.
The way the Metkayina accept the Sullys in the end... 'This is your home now.'
The crab mechs were so cool. I want one.
The whole 'amrita' subplot with the Tulkun brain fluid is so dark.
The beauty of the reef is a perfect contrast to the destruction of the RDA.
The moment Jake's son dies in his arms is a memory that will be seared into my brain forever.
I wonder if the other sea clans will join the fight in the next movie.
The fact that Spider knows all their secrets is a huge liability. Jake should be worried.
The underwater spirit tree was a beautiful new addition to the world.
The 'songcord' tradition is such a beautiful way to track a life story.
Lo'ak constantly trying to prove himself to his dad is classic teen drama.
I can't believe they left us on that cliffhanger with Quaritch. He's definitely coming back.
The movie makes a strong case for becoming a marine biologist on an alien planet.
Kiri's powers are going to be a major factor in the future of Pandora.
The bond with the skimwing creatures was so cool to see.
Seeing the original Tree of Souls destroyed was heartbreaking.
This is a movie you see for the spectacle, and it delivers 100%.
Quaritch's transformation from human to Na'vi gives him a dangerous new perspective.
The funeral scene for Neteyam was beautifully done and so emotional.
The final battle is basically a family-on-family showdown. So intense.
The whole movie is a metaphor for climate change and colonialism, and I'm here for it.
They really made you think Jake was going to die in that sinking ship.
The new characters from the Metkayina clan were great additions.
Lo'ak's decision to go back and save Spider sets up so much conflict.
Visually, this is one of the most stunning films ever made.
The way Kiri connects with the spirit of her mother through Eywa is so touching.
It's not just a movie, it's an experience.
The fact that the RDA is back to colonize, not just mine, raises the stakes so much.
The underwater world felt so real and lived-in.
Payakan's backstory was so tragic. No wonder he's an outcast.
The kids really carried this movie.
The final act had me on the edge of my seat for a solid hour.
I love how the different Na'vi clans have different physiologies adapted to their environment.
The scene where Lo'ak bonds with Payakan is the emotional core of the film.
The flying fish creatures (Skimwings) were my favorite new animal.
Kiri is the key to everything, calling it now.
The themes of family and home are so strong in this one.
The end fight was a direct parallel to the first movie, but with even higher stakes.
